Security is tight at the Little Thunders where the Storm Elves’ military is based. But there’s been a huge mistake! The big mucky-mucks assumed all slaves were spies and evicted every one of them. Now soldiers trained to fight are getting mutinous. Slopping pots makes them so testy they’re concocting any excuse to start a fight. So be careful. Make sure your party isn’t the spark that gets the fight going. Free the Great Dragon instead – he’s raging with a demonic entity inside the storm on top of the towers. Fighting for a Great Dragon, you’re always on the side of the good guys. One more thing? If you can find out where Arvian is, sign him up too. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165344.name: The Blue Flame Wastes
165344.description:
From publisher blurb:

Clashing magics and warring armies have changed the nature of reality forever. The Blue Flame Waste is what remains. There blue light shines from cracks deep in the surface of the earth as though some hidden light source glowed below. Intimidating growths surround the fissures. Blue flames dance above. Yet people live here. A blacksmith with a mystic bent uses the blue flame to fashion swords that are the natural enemies of corruption. Flame hunters capture strange beasts formed from blue fire and sentience combined. A mage priest disguised as a bandit takes captives to the labyrinths below the waste. He sends them off to Mistmoore or Dark Ridge Pass or similar portals of reality shifting magic. For you, adventurer, there’s much to put right here. You’ve got the skills. Just watch your step. This is the edge of the Astral Plane. Don’t slip between the realms.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165345.name: Città Verde
165345.description:
Each player attempts to be the first to build nine buildings in his own land.

At first, the players try to accumulate money through by rolling a special die.

It can be rolled several times, always adding up the results and earning that amount of money, but if the red dot goes out, you lose everything you've earned.

With the money you can build or buy construction licenses that allow counter opponents in constructing their buildings.

When you decide to build, after paying the cost of construction, it may happen that one or more adversaries oppose it, so it will be useful to play as many building permits possible to increase the chances of success of the building.

165346.description:
Two pirate galleons cross paths and a battle is launched! All ye scurvy dogs on deck! But rough seas mean that a little luck goes a long way.

Cannons do the greatest damage, that is when their powder isn’t wet or they don’t miss. But cannons take long to load and you’ll be able to do more attacks by tossing hand mortars, throwing dirks, or firing flintlock pistols.

But those aren’t the only tricks these pirate captains have! Summon a lost pirate from the depths of Davy Jones’ Locker or even persuade an enemy pirate to join your crew!

And, even in the heat of battle, fate can smile down upon this lowly lot and uncover treasure! No pirate can resist treasure – especially if it contains voodoo that helps them fight!

Once you destroy the pirate enemy, you’ve won! Or have you?

The Pirate Ghost gives one last chance and can be a formidable opponent!

Gameplay

Aye, a sworn pirate enemy! Destroy their crew or sink their galleon to win.

Pick your color and roll dice, higher goes first.

Place your pirates on your ship and the matching damage token on your ship's damage counter.

Place the gold cube and Pirate Ghost between the ships.

Shuffle and deal 5 cards face down to each player.

Place remaining deck face down.

1. On your turn discard and draw up to 2 cards, if desired.

2. Play a matching pair and roll the dice. If total matches any of the card's bottom numbers, it wins!

a. Knife, pistol, bomb, or cannon - Take an opponent’s pirate and place it beside your ship as a lost pirate.

Cannon hits are also counted with damage cube. Four cannon hits, your galleon sinks, and you lose the game.

b. Desertion - An opponent's pirate becomes a pirate on your ship.

c. Davy Jones' Locker - Raise any lost pirate and place on your ship.

Doubloons are wild and may be used to complete a pair.

If needed, shuffle discarded cards to continue.

Top right number is the total number of that card in the deck and its chances of success - !!! best, !! fair, ! least

Pirate Ghost!

First one to lose their crew places the Pirate Ghost on their ship and discards 2 cards.

Pirate Ghost plays with only 3 cards unless they have the gold.

Pirate Ghost is always the last lost if you gain crew.

Dice Doubles!

Place gold on your ship and play with an extra card!

If the other player rolls a double, they take your gold and an extra card, and you lose your extra card.

Game interrupted early?

Each standing pirate on your ship is 2 victory points, lost pirates you’ve claimed are 1 point each and 1 point for the gold.

Most victory points win!
165346.name: Mint Tin Pirates
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode Twenty One: YO HO HO and a Frontal Lobotomy

165347.description:
Getting ahead in life often means learning new things and taking on new projects, the Fearless Alien Recruits in Training Program is just what you need.

You go head-to-head against another eager recruit and work hard to earn Merit Awards in what might determine who the next Invasion Leader is. And where does this program take place? Earth, of course!

Show your proficiency with map reading and get to Earth, demonstrate your maneuvering skills by creating crop circles, prove your mastery of advance technology with the abduct-o-tron, and show that you can bend humans to your will with remote mind control!

Don’t miss an assignment or you’ll lose points. But you can make up points by doing extra credit. Even get a bonus for completing one of each Merit Award first!

Game Rules:

Fearless Aliens Recruits in Training! Earn merit awards on Earth!

Gameplay

Shuffle playing cards and deal, face-down, 4 to the first player and 5 to the second. Each player takes a dice with 9 facing up.

Place 5 playing cards face-up in a row and place remaining cards face-down in a pile.

1. First player starts with a card draw. Players have 3 choices for drawing cards:
a. 2 face-down cards
b. 2 face-up cards
c. 1 face-up and 1 face-down card

Face-down moolti-pass cards count as one draw, BUT, face-up moolti-pass counts as BOTH draws. Moolti-pass are wild and can be used as any card(s).

Immediately replace drawn face-up card with a card from the face-down pile.

2. Complete an award, if possible, using cards in hand.

Only 1 award per turn:

2 UFO cards for sightings
2 crop circle cards for we're here
3 cows for abduction
4 brains for mind control




any matching pair for extra credit

Discard played cards into a face-up pile.

3. If completed, take and flip merit award card and place on your side. If you can't complete a merit award, turn your dice down one number (9 to 8 to 7...).

4. Next player’s turn.

First to complete 1 each of "sightings", "we're here", "abduction", and "mind control" gets 2 meeples. Second to complete gets 1 meeple.

If needed, reshuffle discarded face-up cards to continue until all merit awards and extra-credit are completed.

If ALL face-up cards relate to awards that have all been claimed, discard ALL face-up cards and replace from face-down cards.

Scoring

Count your award points, add to that the number of award/extra-credit cards you have, plus 1 point per meeple, plus number on your saucer dice. Highest points win!
165347.name: Mint Tin Aliens
boardgamepodcastepisode: Episode Twenty One: YO HO HO and a Frontal Lobotomy

165348.name: In the Year of the Dragon: The Great Wall of China & The Super Events
boardgamecompilation: In the Year of the Dragon: 10th Anniversary
165348.description:
This expansion contains The Great Wall of China and The Super events.

In The Great Wall of China every player takes the 6 Great Wall tiles in his colour. When a player choose the new action ‘build Great Wall’, he chooses one of his remaining Great Wall tile, he receives from the supply the symbol shown on the tile, then he places this tile under the first event tile. The tiles give: 1 rice, 1 rocket, 2 yuans, 1 palace level, 3 VP, 3 spaces on the order track.

The 10 super event tiles are shuffled face down. Then randomly draw only one of them and put it face up on the 7th event tile. It will be resolved after this event.

This expansion has not been released separately, but can be found in the Alea Treasure Chest.

165349.description:
Each player is dealt 8 cards and the remaining card are placed on the desk face-down to form a draw pile.
The first player picks up a card from the draw pile and determines if it helps him in constructing his "meal" with the cards that he has, he then keeps the card and discards one...
A meal is formed with 5 food cards: veggie + fruit + "protein" or meat card + juice or "drink" card + bread or "carb" card.

After a player discards, play moves to the next person going clockwise...

While constructing a meal, the player can substitute one card with the Q card. However, a veggie card can't be substituted as veggies make integral part of a healthy meal :)

Once you've constructed a meal, put the meal on the desk for everyone to see. If you've used a Q card to substitute a food card (let's say your meal doesn't have a Fruit card and you've used a Q card to replace it), another player can insert a Fruit card on your meal as process of gradually discarding his cards...

Aside from this function of substitution, Q card can be used: a) to neutralize a junk card that has been used to destroy a meal.
b) with a Q card you can ask (during your turn) another player (whose turn is after you) to show you a random card from the ones that he is holding (you don't get to see the card before picking it) and you can decide 1) to keep the card for you and put your Q card on the discard pile OR 2) you can decide not to take the card from the other player and keep your Q card.

Junk card: the only function of this card is to destroy a healthy meal. There's nothing healthy about junk food. Players can discard this card by using it to destroy someone else's meal. All you need to do is place a junk card next to a meal...
The only way to neutralize a junk card is to put a put a Q card after it...Ex: if you have 3 cards in hand and you've already created a meal, and someone places a junk card on your meal, you can neutralize that junk card by placing a Q card on it (if you have one or are lucky to draw one)

Unlike most other card games, Qetchup doesn't require you to always draw a card and discard one during your turn. While this is certainly an option for an intuitive game play, you can simply discard a card by using one of it's functions. Ex: by placing a junk card to mess up someone's meal OR using a food card to add to a meal where Q card has been used to substitute it( without having to pick another card from the draw pile).

If you have a Restart card, you can use it to make any other player restart their game from scratch by choosing a fresh set of 8 cards (that even if he's constructed a meal | his entire meal and discard pile are then shuffled back in with the existing draw pile to form a new draw pile from which he gets 8 new cards) Restart card goes back in the discard pile.
165349.name: Qetchup Card Game

165350.name: Notre Dame: The New Persons
165350.description:
This expansion provides 9 new character cards.

The 18 grey character cards (the 9 old ones and the 9 new ones) are sorted by the letter on their back to form 3 stacks of 6 cards. Those 3 stacks are shuffled independently. Then play the game as usual.

This expansion has not been released separately, but can be found in the Treasure Chest.

165351.name: Louis XIV: The Favourite
165351.description:
The Favourite expansion includes 4 Favourite Tablets and a Favourite figure.

Each player takes a Favourite tablet and put it in front of him, in view of every player. Then each player takes one influence marker from the general supply and places it on one of the 4 space of his Favourite tablet.

This expansion has not been released separately, but can be found in the Treasure Chest.

165353.name: Aces Gin Rummy
165353.description:
Get ready for a card game that makes all other forms of entertainment look like deadwood!

The cards are dealt. You pass on the up-card and draw from the stock. Two melds already and you’ve only drawn once! Sort the high cards down and discard that king. Not much deadwood, but if you knock now, you might get undercut. It’s risky either way, but you hang in there, hoping for a spade or a seven.
One more draw…and…GIN!

Cast of Characters
Want to play Gin Rummy against an elegant Victorian skunk? We’ve got you covered. How about a dapper beaver in a collar and waistcoat? You can do that too. With 11 different animated characters to choose from, including a variety of well dressed ladies and gentlemen (and equally well dressed farm animals and robots), our cast of quirky characters will charm the aces out of you.

Gameplay For All Skill Levels
If you’re new to Gin Rummy, don’t worry. The EASY difficulty setting is a great way to ease into the game. If you’re looking for more of a challenge, HARD will have you planning every move and really watching the discards. Whatever your skill level, our adjustable difficulty system has the right setting for you.
Traditional Scoring

Games in Gin Rummy can be customized to be played to 100 (if you’re looking for a quick game), 150, 250 or 300 (if you’d like a game that lasts a bit longer). Scoring follows classic rules with a 100 point bonus for winning, a 20 point bonus for each hand won, and double points for shutting out your opponent!

Source: The Developer Website.

165354.name: Witch's Brew: The 6th Player & The Amulets & The Magical Abilities
165354.description:
Expansion I, The 6th player:
Note that you can also use this expansion with less than 6 players.

Expansion II, The Amulets:
This expansion increases the tension and the excitement, in particular with 3 players.

Expansion III, Magic Powers:
With this expansion the choice of role cards at the beginning of each round is now more important and require more planning.

This expansion has not been released separately, but can be found in the Treasure Chest.

165355.description:
Expansion I,The New Buildings
The 31 new cards (26 violet buildings and 5 factories), are shuffled with the cards from the basic game.

Expansion II, The Events:
6 different event cards are added.
During the game every time an event card is revealed face up, whether it be during the card’s distribution at the beginning of the game, during the councilor phase, the trader phase, the prospector phase, by using the power of a building or by the resolution of an event, this card is placed face up alongside the character tiles in the middle of the table, and a replacement card is drawn immediately.

This expansion has not been released separately, but can be found in the Treasure Chest.

The buildings (but not the events) were also included in the 2014 edition of San Juan, along with a new building not previously available in any version: The Hut.
165355.name: San Juan: The New Buildings & The Events

165356.name: Racial Guide 2: Culture & Class
165356.description:
From publisher blurb:

When someone thinks of fantasy, certain genre-defining races come to the front of the mind. Surprisingly throughout the years, the basic attributes of these races have remained the same despite sweeping changes to the worlds around them. It begs the question “What makes these races what they are?” Just being born an elf doesn’t mean they’ll be an archer or mage, despite both archetypes being explored in detail over the years. We took examples from real world cultures and analyzed the different archetypes these races fill, what makes them perceived as they are and what makes them stand out in the minds of fans across the globe. Within are suggestions on how to create a culture in your game that enhances your races and world, with mechanical reinforcement to help bring them to life. With specialized classes from some of our favorite fiction, reimaginings of races into new archetypal roles and a boatload of racial feats from the excellent Christos “+5 Toaster” Gurd, you’ll be hard pressed to think of the peoples that make up your setting of choice in the same way ever again.

New Prestige Classes


Magelord [Elf]: Part politician, part specialist mage with the unique "arcane cascade" mechanic.
Bladesinger [Elf]: Part magus, part arcane archer, part bard- all elven grace.
Emissary [Human]: A human who adopts elements of another race/faction in order to gain bonuses against their enemies.
Battlesmith [Dwarf]: He crafts, he fights, and he drinks (hopefully in that order). This presents unique options for crafting with materials (advanced alloys and the like).
Grudge Seeker [Dwarf]: When you think your wife holds a grudge, you've never meet a pissed off dwarf.
Alpha [Werewolf]: A feral, raging, pack leader who grants his allies rage bonuses.
Skysinger [Werewolf]: She sings for the sun and she sings for the moon, but when it's all done she's got your heart... and forces you to shift forms.



New Base Class


Underhero [Halfling]: A fun little base class designed to be the "underdog". Not optimized for damage dealing but posed for those Tolkien fans who want to play the clever little hobbit.



Race Mechanics Rewrites & Re-Imaginings

Grippli [Reimagining] [Mechanics Rewrite]: Let’s face it, you ALWAYS wanted to play a blustering, adventurous, ripped, heroic, crazy little frog person.
High Dwarves (“Gustavin”) [Racial Subgroup]: Who wants to live in a smelly little cave when there are so many High Gothic castles for sale?
Sahmeii [Subgroup]: Part merfolk, part human, all OGL.
Wild Elves (“Elva’stana”) [Subgroup]: They are not so much the "let's sing in the forest without harps" kind of elves and more of the "let’s wrestle that T-Rex before it eats us" kind of elves.
Centaur (“Mek Centid”) [Mechanics Rewrite]: Centaurs re-balanced as a player race.
Ghost Elves ["Nef’liem"]: Soulless outcast elves who sought to avoid punishment by sleeping for 300 years.



New Racial Feats For:


Dhampir
Fetchlings
Gillmen
Gnolls
Kitsune
Lizardfolk
Merfolk
Nagaji
Samsaran
Strix
Suli
Svirfneblin
Vanara
Vishkanya
Wayang

165357.name: Racial Guide 3: Races of the Darkness
165357.description:
From publisher blurb:

We are proud to present Racial Guide 3: Races of Darkness! This installment focuses on new races found primarily in and around the underdark. The book is loaded with lore (politics, geology, culture, etc), new mechanics (darkness as a terrain type for example), 15 deities (ever wonder what a troll deity was like?), 15 new racial weapons, kobold line guns (and siege cannons), 17 new feats, and...

Included:

Arachno (Drider)
Dark Folk
Derros
Kabouters
Kobolds: Jaksear
Kobolds: Svarik
Pechs
Sunkids
Trolls




We’ve also got your class needs covered!

Ancestral Bloodline Sorcerer: Mix your power with those who came before for immense flexibility!
Black Widow: A cursed prestige that mutates you into a spider abomination!
Bloodseekers: Drow anti-paladin archetype for followers of the Spider Queen.
Cave Stalker: A underground svirfneblin ranger archetype for stealth experts of all sorts.
Dark Hunter: A duergar ranger archetype that overcomes their racial weakness to sunlight!

165358.name: The Princes of Florence: The Muse and the Princess
165358.description:
The Princes of Florence: The Muse and the Princess expansion adds 6 special character cards and a second auction phase.
From the rules:
"The expansion adds 6 special character cards which players can bid on in a second part of the auction phase. Thus, the auction phase has been split into two phases: the original auction phase and special character auction."

This expansion has not been released separately, but can be found in the Treasure Chest (only in Rio Grande version) and it is included in the recent versions of the game.

Contents:
6 special character cards
1 rule sheet

165359.name: The Oiler's Cup
165359.description:
From publisher blurb:

When the colonists came to Port Morganti, only some were in the know. Those who weren’t got slaughtered. Now the Faith of the Five is in full denial – even building a temple with its bloody hands. The game plan is to keep mum about the massacre. But Riselian Hawkins, proprietor of the Oilers’ Cup, is suspicious. Tongues slip. He hears. There are survivors, too. That girl who waits tables? She witnessed her father die. Now the satyr, Bryn, is bringing her two heads a night - an effort to identify the guy who did it. So here’s the plan. Stop the satyr’s slaughter first. Then set up some simple law and order. And stay out of the fairy circle. Keep clear of the church basement too and the portal there to the astral plane. Neither’s marked, but there’s a map. Keep it simple. Clean the place up.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165360.name: The Kobolds' Temple
165360.description:
From publisher blurb:

A long time ago the Great Dragons won the War of Corruption. Temples were erected to their memory to keep them remembered. Then they rested. But memories fade. Now the Third Age is emerging, the Dragons are waking. They’re talking to a little kobold - Gyr’s his name - and he lives in one of their dragon temples. But what can Gyr do? He’s got no cred. Fortunately there’s a scruffy scholar living in the temple. He passes as a god, but knows his dragons. A barbarian warrior princess is scouting the temple too. She wants the totems back the kobolds steal from her borders. Then there’s a stash of scholar bones awaiting burial. Yes. More than a few interest groups here, looking to hire adventurers. Dragon translators are needed and some muscle behind them. Sign up or make your mark for the Dragons. They’re the good guys.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165361.name: The Tailor's Shop
165361.description:
From publisher blurb:

If you’re looking for some action, see Dwiven. Really? A tailor? Stash the skepticism. Dwiven was a career assassin long before he broke his back. Truth be told, even before the catastrophe, Dwiven found sewing and designing calming. He sewed for himself – clothes, but actually they were weapons. Now Dwiven stitches for those in the know and on the side brokers clients and assassins together. He has plenty of side jobs as well that he parcels out to adventurers. He might give you one, weaponize you too. How about a little lead in the hem of a cloak? Maybe one of dragon silk? Pricy, yes, but great for lighting tunnels. Ask to meet Athilea, too – a nice, safe friend of Dwiven’s. She only practices transitory assassinations. Along with a shop boy caught in intransigent adolescence - you’ll find a good support crew at the Tailor’s Shop. Savvy, too. Fun.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165362.name: The Weeping Crater
165362.description:
From publisher blurb:

Rain rises out of the Weeping Crater and falls upon the land along the rim. Lush farms there feed the Elven Commonwealth. It’s a friendly area. Elves and non-elves live here, not as equals, but, at least, side by side. Don’t venture down the crater, though. It’s not safe. Wait for maps. If you can’t wait, cartographer Amyian is on the job right now and you could join her. She’s got a whole entourage – adjunct artists as well as lots of adventurers sturdy enough to brave the unknowns down below. Join her if she’ll have you. A few words of caution, though. There’s trouble brewing between the Elven Supremacists and the lesser nationals in the rimlands. And there’s a young necromancer to keep sights on. Don’t take him lightly. So, caution, all around. But check out the lake. Rumor says the beach is Ulgdish spirits.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165363.name: Iron Wall
165363.description:
From publisher blurb:

Iron Wall harbors some strange characters. But, hey. It’s never fallen and even though it’s positioned between dire enemies, it’s mostly safe. The elves even call it “The Nail” swearing it holds everything together. Maybe so, but that doesn’t mean it doesn’t need help. There are lots of jobs for adventurers here. Balster – that guy with the little silver drill on his belt? He even knows your name. He wants you to kill the Great Dragons. Maudline wants to double cross the party in a scheme with the Barbarians and the Magistrate wants some nasties stirred up to the top. So choose your poison. But a thing you should know – Iron Wall is a double city. Down below is something that’s not just an archeological dig. Ugly things live down there and they use powerful, ancient relics for weapons. #114 is not for the timid - it’s for you.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165364.name: Old Bridge
165364.description:
From publisher blurb:

It was on his birthday that Gotrain dreamed and saw the prognostication of his death. His witch soothed him “No worries,” she lied. But she had seen death too in the bones of halfling children and the livers of squalling cats. It didn’t matter that Gotrain depended on her. The Storms had chosen her to get him to the Black Flame Bridge and manipulate events to the will of the Godslayer. That’s the set up. The party is lining up - banding together to play out strange, new rhythms in history. You get to save Gotrain with the spy from the musical society, or kill him off in the service of the thief queen of the Umbra. How about you? Can you see the end of the Black Flame Bridge? Does it hang in space for you or go on forever? Whichever -watch your step. You’re the next act.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165365.name: Executioner's Square
165365.description:
From publisher blurb:

The executioner’s mask is black and looks like flame. There’s not even an eye hole, so you’ll never glimpse the guy behind it. Attendance at executions is compulsory and more ominous still? You’ll feel whatever the condemned feels – the bite of the ax, the fear, the helplessness. Now it’s Meldonia’s turn to die. She got ripped into slavery very young – though not as young as she looked. Powered up with adolescent defiance, she transformed herself into a rebel leader. Now her head is on the block. But wait – looks like you’ll have to grab her from under the ax itself. So this is the plan: get some walk-away stones, teleport the whole party to a predestined destination that will be a mystery until you get there. But what’s to lose? No place is worse than Executioner’s Square, so rescue the green-eyed rebel. Iron Wall? That’s her destination of choice.

Toys for the Sandbox is not a module, it is not a campaign setting, instead it is a framework for GMs to use to reinforce their own imaginations. Sometimes players zig when you expect them to zag, other times they take your plot point into a back alley and leave it penniless and bleeding. Each week we present a new location with a map and some flavor text. In addition we add 4 NPCs with a bit of history and a few simple thoughts on how to stat them for whatever game you are playing. There are also 6 plot hooks each with 3 ways to twist them. Added to that there is usually a table or two filled with rumors and encounters.

165366.name: The Forest of the Giants
165366.description:
From publisher blurb:

From the first, the forest wasn’t perfect for these sad, old ancients. They got washed ashore, after all. No choices. Good hearted ents came and stayed with them, but times later the giants died and the ents - caregivers by nature - were left out of whack with the rest of the world. The ents got put to work as smuggler helpers, making the Forest of the Giants feared and shunned by just about everybody. That’s good for smuggling, but it can’t go on. Essential equipment to sort this thing out? You’ll need an Ent Tongue Organ for sure to calm these guys down. They’re trees, don’t forget. Gestures and rustling will never get you far. And look for the grave of the last ancient. Rumor has it Sharinti or some other librarian might be there. They’re smart. They talk ent. They will help

165367.name: The Way Station
165367.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Unnamed is at the Way Station. Commonwealth soldiers bivouacked there are disgusted. The Unnamed stinks. It stinks of fish and barnacles and human waste. They hold their noses, oblivious that the Unnamed is what they are actually there for. Best they don’t know. Best, even for you not to look closely – not to see the empty eye sockets lost in the hood, swirling a tapestry of cosmic stars. Be warned. Even the voice of the Unnamed can damage paltry human stuff. Yet, you’ve got a job here. You must help it. No Joke. Use your puny power to aid the Unnamed. It may be the avatar of the Dead God, but it’s going to become what you guide it to become. Right now, it’s only on the edge of real. Your job? Influence the Unnamed and usher in a golden era for the mortals of the Third Age.

165368.name: The Dread Pit
165368.description:
From publisher blurb:

There is another version of the world, a sinister version where dark gods plot conquest. The Dread Pit is their portal and, though the pit has been sealed off for some time, Ambostus finds it. The portal is a clockwork construct with winding and unwinding springs. He slides a lever into the slowly moving gears and that unseals it. They say the Dread Pit was used to kill a god and that may be true, but one thing is certain. When the pit was sealed, Commonwealth soldiers got locked inside. Now they’re free. In a sense. So is former slave, Ambostus. But freedom doesn’t mean anyone is going to live happily ever after. It’s time to stick some shivs in this plot amalgam and determine how the changes forced upon these guys get writ as history. Help them, or don’t, but be careful - don’t step on the runes.

165369.name: Galaxy Conquest
165369.description:
Galaxy Conquest is a free print and play two-player game.

OVERVIEW
Galaxy Conquest is a game where two player wage in a space war against each other. Compete to win planets. One of the players will take control of the Terran of Hammer Wing Faction and the other Kryak of Thunder Faction.

GOAL
The goal of Galaxy Conquest is to be the first to win 3 planets by smartly placing your unit tokens on the planets, and utilising the abilities you acquired.

SETUP
1. Each player chooses a faction (Hammer Wing (Blue) or Thunder Faction (Red)) and gathers all the unit tokens of the faction chosen near.
2. Shuffle the planet deck and place 4 cards in the middle of the table then place the planet deck faced down somewhere on the table.
3. Place the arrow tokens on the designated faction on the planets faction control (dotted faction means initial faction)
Determining the First Player
The player who has fewer faction controlled planet initially is the starting player. If there is tie, both players randomly choose who will be the starting player.

PLAYING THE GAME
Players will take turn to play one action each turn. A player can choose to play 1 of 4 actions available:

Gain 1 unit – Player takes 1 unit from own unit token pile and places it on any planet.
Remove 1 unit – Player removes any 1 unit from any planet.
Change faction control – Player changes the planet’s faction control on a chosen planet.
Use ability – Player uses 1 ability on any planet they control.




GAME END
The game ends when a player has won 3 planets. The player who won 3 planets wins the game and earns himself the title of Galaxy Conquest!

165370.name: The Harpies' Rookery
165370.description:
From publisher blurb:

At the very bottom of Weeping Crater is an island where the rain falls up instead of down and a priest gone bad is stuck cooking for harpies. (Nasty, filthy things.) He hardly gets a bite himself as he slogs through the centuries living out a punishment for gluttony. But now things are changing. Harpy matriarch Aello’s great-great-great grandmother predicted that when clouds covered the sun, monsters would fall from the sky - scary stuff because now there are clouds. Aello is worried - old too. Her wings are crumpled and arthritic. She wants the party to get her out of the crater. The priest wants out too. And the cartographer from #113? She may need help as well. She’s still down there, mapping the crater floor. But aid is close at hand - harpy feather tea helps with travel. Just boil it long and nobody will get sick.

165371.name: The Small Grass Sea
165371.description:
From publisher blurb:

There were Seven Great Dragons. They built the Ziggurat and were going to save the world. But then one got corrupted. He transformed into the Dragon God and cut an evil swath through history. In Toys #121 the Seventh Great Dragon sets out to corrupt the Land of Fallen Gods. His herald is approaching the barbarian tribes there, armed and striding through the Grass Sea with an entourage of priests. He is called the Advent. The Advent is powered by those hideous gemstones that have wreaked havoc time and again throughout the Toys saga. The Advent carries two staves of them radiating gemstone evil. Good luck, puny humans. But no excuses. The Grass Sea is a holy place. You can tap into its power with prayer and some Ulgdish spirits. Strap on some stilts and run like the Red Grass Clan does. You can win this one.

165372.name: Crèche of the Storm Elves
165372.description:
From publisher blurb:

All storm elves get born in a crèche - but don’t think Christmas and Jesus in the manger. Think vats of harvested body parts in amniotic fluid, primed with heroes’ blood. You’ll meet the Harvester in #122. He’s a cool guy. Always happy and a master of his work. He keeps his scalpels sharp, and carves to prolong life as long as possible. Nothing wrong with that, though the unquiet souls do stack up. Roco is on their side. He belongs to the Order of Sleep, and yes he’s a necromancer, but his strongest desire is to bring peace to the undead. He and his sheep are going to take on the ovoid, black-glass crèche. He will need protection. You will too, but Roco knows some tricks. And all those kids? Crèche kids stay in the crèche until they’re grown. Saving them is up to you. Ready or not.

165373.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Grootslag has been a power below the Horidian Waste for eons, but the Low Road takes you through his domain and you’re going to have to deal with him. Pulling down magical energy from the waste above and from the ulgdain spirits he wallows in, the Grootslag has been making clumsy, elephant-headed spider troops for ages. But no worry, they are not smart, and Mowdain the Red will be on your side. He is seriously studying on eliminating the Grootslag altogether - his weird invented minions too. Mowdain himself is dangerous, of course, but if you want to be a hero? Don’t wait for a miracle. Mowdain will lead you into trouble, possibly grief, but if you are motivated to obliterate this ugly Grootslag thing, this is your best bet. Depend on Grounding Irons to discharge the magic of the waste. Other than that? You’re on your own.

165374.name: The Apiary
165374.description:
From publisher blurb:

What could be sweeter than honey? Magical honey, of course. Only problem is, it’s only made in Weeping Crater jungle. Very, very dangerous place there, so if you have the where-with-all, don’t harvest it yourself. Send someone else – a slave maybe and send Chethrean along to fight off the bandits. She’s available to the highest bidder and if you want tough, Chethrean is tough. She took back her soul after going through the Black Flame Rites at Thunder Crèche and, for extra punch, her teacher’s soul is in a locket at her throat. She wants something, but it will probably dovetail right into your own hopes and needs. Just let her live down in the ruins when the fighting’s over. One word of caution? Careful with the honey. Just a spoonful might make medicine go down, but then there’s this honey. No recalls yet, but watch for sudden mutations.

165375.description:
From publisher blurb:

Execution isn’t an option in the Commonwealth. As a work around, the nation suspends really bad guys - dangles them down below Sky City. They think this method is foolproof. But, really? Not so much. Nobody can lock up the truth, so when they suspend a traitorous priest, they find his ideas have wings. His body, though still needs rescuing. You could do it. You’ve got a pretty good chance of busting him out thanks to the Dragon Writ Armor he wears that lets him foil the powers of evil. So get your papers in order and head to Sky City. Just be warned – Sky Prison is a hive of racism. Gendra, a winged guard loathes humans. All humans. Theragain, ditto for elves. So factor that in. 165376.description:
From publisher blurb:

You leave a half dead litch hanging in a meadow somewhere and what do you get? Nothing good. His power has to drain somewhere and if there’s no proper vessel, evil is going to infect the very roses growing up around him. That’s what happened in Port Morganti. Go to the meadow outside town there and you’ll find a Mother Rose of ominous power with uncounted numbers of pale, human shaped minions grown up around her. Though the fondest hope of the litch’s progeny is to finish the half dead thing off, the roses have become a valuable commodity used to make an efficient poison. If the litch goes, what happens to the roses? If the roses go, what happens to the litch? Can the world get by without the poison? Walls of roses are cutting off Port Morganti. No time to lollygag. 165377.name: The Giant's Grave
165377.description:
From publisher blurb:

“I am the gods’ anger,” Dagrum proclaims rising up from the Giant’s Grave. It doesn’t bode well that he’s imbued with the teachings of the ancients and able to work malevolent miracles. It’s not so good either that he speaks like a human and practices human ways. He never did have any positive potential, but the psychological studies a wizard did on him as a baby ogre gave him tools to fine tune his instinctual rage. Now Dagrum is living proof of the power of the ancient grave. Others, too, are being drawn there and are converging. A mummified magician is waiting for the key that will unlock the spell he’s working and a treasure hunter digging by the skull suddenly finds himself taken over by an ancient. 165378.name: The Necromancer's Fortress
165378.description:
From publisher blurb:

Still proudly wearing his tattered grave clothes, Karsis, Mummy Caliph of the Necromancers is returned from the grave. Having successfully sought out and conquered death, he has taken as his fortress a lighthouse that stands amongst brutal seas on a skinny finger of land. From there he abducts apprentices and breaks the ones he can. Like the Captain of the Ship of Bones – she was always a keeper - never broken, still human and so jubilantly cruel she sloughs off compassion like a tarantula its skin. Her craft of bones speaks volumes about her, so watch her skeletons swarm and don’t aggravate her. Also be warned about the necromancer’s staff. It wants a new owner and thinks you’re it. It will control you, not empower you, so don’t mess with it. Plenty ways to be a hero here, so be your own person and avoid the Necromancer’s bossy staff.

From publisher blurb:

When time stands still you don’t have to sleep and you don’t have to eat. That means travel light - leave your bed roll behind. Just bring yourself to the Timeless Waste where you’re needed to keep the world on an even keel. You’ve got a bad disease like lycanthropy? Then timelessness is a good thing. You won’t have another full moon to suffer through. But timelessness opens wiggle room for the bad guys to get back to the past and manipulate the squeakers of history they lost. Hind sight is 20/20, they say, and corrupted dragon fighters are going to sneak through and use it. Want to refight the War of Corruption? That would be a bad thing, or so thinks Dragon legionnaire, Dealth standing forever at the gate of the Timeless Waste. Listen up. He’s calling for reinforcements. Calling you. Prop up the status quo. Please. Now.

165380.name: Pro Cycling Manager Season 2014: Le Tour de France
165380.description:
Would you like to experience the sensations of a professional rider competing in the “Grande Boucle”? Then immerse yourself in an incredible virtual Tour de France 2014 on PlayStation®4, PlayStation®3 and Xbox 360®!

Select from one of the official teams and take part in this supreme test of endurance. Compete as one of the riders in a bid to reach the Holy Grail of professional cycling: the yellow jersey! Go on a reconnaissance trip of a specific stage, decide the composition of your team and the rider with whom you will start the race and then launch into the epic stages. The English countryside, the route through London with its iconic landmarks, a cobbled stage in Northern France (every rider’s nightmare), the grueling mountain stages or a solo time trial that could in fact decide the winner!

Source: The Developer Website.

165381.name: Pro Cycling Manager Season 2006: Le Tour de France
165381.description:
Pro Cycling Manager is a sport management game dedicated to cyclism, mixing tactical experience and strategy. Playing a sport director, you have to manage, plan, and organize the life of a professional team on one season or more, and mainly have an impact on its results in the various races in real time and 3D graphics. In the races, you will have to ask your riders to manage their energy, to get some fresh water and food, to attack at the right moment, to protect your leader, to keep an eye on your competitors or to launch sprints… You will the discover all the tactical subtleties of professional cycling!

Pro Cycling Manager 2006 offers you to run in the greatest international events in cycling. In this new edition, well-known teams as Jan Ullrich’s “T-Mobile” are completing an already big pack of 50 official teams (for example: Bouygues Telecom, Cofidis, Crédit Agricole, Davitamon Lotto, Euskaltel, Française des Jeux, Quickstep, Rabobank, Team CSC, Lampre, Liberty Seguros, AG2r Prévoyance, Caise d’épargne Iles Baléares, among others!).

Pro Cycling Manager 2006 benefits for the first time of the prestigious licence “Tour de France” and offers races such as: Paris-Nice, Paris-Roubaix, La Fleche Wallone, Liège-Bastogne-Liège, Paris-Tours, le Critérium international, le Tour de Picardie, le Tour de l’avenir, and so one… Thus season 2006 is full of great events for Pro Cycling manager’s fans with 400 stages!

Source: The Developer Website.

165382.name: Pro Cycling Manager Season 2009: Le Tour de France
165382.description:
Pro Cycling Manager 2009 is a cycling management video game. It was released just before the 2009 Tour de France (PCM 2009 is the Tour de France licensed game).

The game was released for Windows and PSP. A Tour de France-only game was released for the Xbox 360 but was only available to buy from the Xbox Live Arcade. On this version of the game there are only 5 riders per team which means that there are only 90 riders in the race, although you get to choose from the whole squad of the teams to choose the riders. The Fuji-Servetto team are in the game although they didn't compete in the Tour de France in 2009. They are in place of the Cervélo TestTeam.

Source: Wikipedia, "Pro Cycling Manager 2009", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

165384.name: Alien Spidy
165384.description:
Source: Wikipedia, "Alien Spidy", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Alien Spidy is a physics-based platformer video game. Players control the eponymous Spidy, an extraterrestrial spider, and navigate him through a series of levels that are filled with deadly obstacles. Spidy can run and jump, and has the ability to shoot a web, allowing him to grapple and swing from object to object within the environment. Interspersed throughout each level are a large number of orbs, which Spidy can collect to score points. Finishing the level quickly, collecting a large number of orbs, collecting several orbs in quick succession, and finding score multipliers all increase the player's score for that level. Players can also lose points by dying, collecting certain orbs that decrease the player's score, or going for too long without collecting an orb. Players earn between one and five stars on each level, based on their score. Levels are grouped into several stages, including a forest, a pond, a cave system, and outer-space. In order to progress from one stage to the next, players must collect a certain number of stars. Players can collect special power-up orbs scattered throughout levels. These orbs allow Spidy to perform feats he is otherwise incapable of, including traveling underwater and jumping to extreme heights. There are 69 levels in the game, and most of them take between 90 seconds and three minutes.

165386.name: Standard Action: Legend of the Lonely Dragon
165386.description:
UNRELEASED GAME – IN BETA




This game is in Beta and has not been fully released yet.




User Summary

Standard Action: Legend of the Lonely Dragon is a web browser RPG that is based on the fantasy comedy series Standard Action.

165387.name: BlackSoul: Extended Edition
165387.description:
User Summary

BlackSoul is a third person survival horror adventure game that takes place somewhere in the English countryside, in 1972. An unknown infection has been spreading around, turning people into psychotic killers. As a player, your job is to help two characters, Ava and Sean survive and learn the truth about the infection.

165388.description:
From the back of the box:

For Professor Winston Nurfle, planes and zeppelins always seemed much too large. Instead, he felt that each man, woman and child should have their own flying propulsion unit. Finally, Nurfle stumbled up the perfect mixture of explosive chemicals to provide thrust for his jet pack. But now, with the wars consuming most research and development Nurfle has donned his prototype and gotten into the fight! He has vowed to prove the combat effectiveness of his invention!
165388.name: Rivet Wars: The Jetpacker

165389.name: Hexcells Infinite
165389.description:
Hexcells Infinite is the third game in the Hexcells series. Puzzles in the game are best described as a mix between Minesweeper and Picross.

Like other games in the series, Hexcells Infinite features 36 hand-crafted puzzles. The novelty, this time, is the infinite mode that can randomly generate an infinity of puzzles (hence the title).

165394.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing – Silver Dragon Expansion Pack
boardgamefamily: Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing Miniatures Game

boardgamefamily: Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing Miniatures Game

165396.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing – Wyvern Expansion Pack
boardgamefamily: Dungeons & Dragons: Attack Wing Miniatures Game

165397.name: The Lasting Victory
165397.description:
From publisher blurb:

It’s a lie. Elves aren’t superior. Long ago elves kicked halflings out of their homeland with that powerful lie and built consensus on the battlefield, making everybody believe it. But as far as the halflings are concerned, nothing’s settled yet. They want a just and lasting victory - one that lets them go home. Halflings are mostly assimilated in Iron Wall and run a thriving inn there. They call it the Lasting Victory. They lay a fine table, serve a mean meal and the décor is spiffy. But it’s a front. The Lasting Victory is a cover for spies working to put elves in their place and get halflings back home. They’re waiting for you there, so it’s time you got serious. Go to the Lasting Victory. The Laughing Monkey will have a prophecy for you there. He won’t be joking, so listen up and act.

165398.description:

Below the Screaming Valley and its population of Mudmen, the Dragon of Mercy sleeps. Veronica has been called to wake him. She was just a mousy girl - so much smaller than her place in history - until she got tapped for this job by the God of Magic. Now armored up, with hair sun-bleached and flying, Veronica is changing the tempo of history. #131 is a consolidating and seminal issue. The Falcon Guards are back looking for Lightstealer and a storm elf with twisted melt marks on his face is working to eradicate the blue flame he got in the crèche. The Mudmen can’t survive what’s going to happen next here. But wait - Veronica constructs magical fortresses that bridge the planes of reality, so escape routes might be available. 165399.name: The Lighting Waste
165399.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Godslayer got banished to Pirate Island when he killed a god, but that doesn’t mean he can’t see all futures and just about everything else as well. But there is one place the Godslayer can’t see – just one. That’s the Lightning Waste where the Thunderbird sits on a nest of lightning bolts shooting down corruption. That rankled the Godslayer so he instigated false prophecy rumors to bring war to the tree where the great bird sits protecting its eggs. The Godslayer wants the tree destroyed. The Thunderbird needs to be protected. So do her eggs. Adventurers are signing up and taking body parts the Thunderbird has shed for protection. Talons and feathers and gastroliths all have powers. This battle is a fight to keep corruption at bay, so do your bit and save the Thunderbird. Just beware – stay in the circle of time that the Godslayer can’t see.
